awd_titl_txt: Increasing Technician Preparedness in the Built Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
This project from Sinclair Community College has a focus on providing community college students, including under represented populations, an opportunity to master STEM competencies and industry standards in demand by employers, and to increase graduate employability in a variety of "built environment" jobs.  With architecture technician occupations changing rapidly due to the growing complexity of today's construction industry, this project will transform associate degree programs by embedding critical STEM and industry standards from the Construction Document Technologist (CDT) certificate into two-year education programs. The CDT credential was chosen because it is recognized by employers as a respected entry-level credential and addresses significant gaps in undergraduate education.

With a strong involvement from industry, workforce development will be enabled by involving forty college faculty nationwide to develop and disseminate new curricular modules for undergraduate students enrolled in architectural technician and construction management associate degree programs.  The project will enable professional development of community college faculty and staff.  Not only will over nineteen hundred community college students be impacted by this project, but project outcomes will also be disseminated to other institutions with educational programs in the built environment. The targeted focus on diversifying their student populations is a strength of the project, as is the direct value to students and graduate job-seekers who will be better able to certify their knowledge and skills to employers. The long-term outcome will be a more diversified workforce that better meets the needs of built environment professions.

por.por_cntn:
Increasing Technician Preparedness in the Built Environment – Project Outcomes Report

Sinclair Community College (Dayton, OH), in collaboration with partners: Columbus State Community College (Columbus, OH); Montgomery College (Rockville, MD); the Coalition of Community College Architecture Programs (representing 122 colleges nationwide); and the Construction Specifications Institute (a national, non-profit industry professional association in Alexandria, VA), were awarded grant funding from the National Science Foundation’s (NSF) Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Program to develop and disseminate new curricular modules for undergraduate students enrolled in built environment educational programs and provide professional development for community college faculty and staff. The goal of the project was to provide community college students with an opportunity to master STEM competencies and industry standards that are in demand by employers and to increase graduate employability in a variety of built environment jobs.

The project team successfully worked with the Construction Specifications Institute (CSI) and a task force of 15 industry professionals to align the knowledge and skills to be tested on the new Construction Documents Technology exam (CDT) exam with industry needs. Twenty-four community college architectural programs across the county agreed to join the project’s efforts by incorporating new content into their curricula to prepare students for the newly aligned CDT credential. By the end of the project, more than half of the participating institutions had incorporated at least some of the new CDT content elements into their curricula and five had incorporated all of the new elements. Students had been encouraged but were not required, to sit for the CSI CDT certification exam. By the end of the project, 161 students had taken the CDT with a passing rate of 39%. During the first three years of the project from 2017 to 2019 the team provided annual opportunities for faculty from participating institutions to attend a “summer institute” hosted by the project team. Data from participant surveys after these events indicated that participants appreciated learning more about the goals and expectations of the BEprep project as well as the guidance they received in terms of incorporating CDT content into their curricula. Participants also valued the opportunity to meet colleagues from other institutions to share experiences and ideas.

The project team learned key lessons that will inform their own efforts on similar projects in the future and will provide valuable information to others planning similar initiatives. Any future efforts by the project team to enhance students’ STEM competencies and employment preparedness will include the consideration of other credentials that can be earned more easily in terms of easier access to content including learning material and practice tests. By targeting credentials that are easier to earn, students could develop a sense of success and achievement as they build towards larger certifications.

The project team began the process of establishing a centralized portal for sharing instructional content among the participating educational institutions and found that the success of this kind of effort requires open communication among contributing members and a centralized process to facilitate content submission, vetting, and posting. The channels of communication across participating institutions built through this project will remain and will be leveraged in its continued efforts to build the content portal.

Finally, the project team had hoped to collect student-level data from participating institutions to identify aspects related to the incorporation of CDT content and student-related factors associated with success on the CDT exam. However, despite being provided with clear guidelines and offers of support from the project team - faculty at partnering institutions did not have the experience or time needed to acquire the data. Project teams engaged in similar efforts should determine if the information they hope to gather is critical enough to warrant the considerable resources that will be required to collect it. If so, the project team highly recommends that a contact person who is in a data-gathering role at each institution be identified early in the project and that funding is provided to cover the costs of their efforts.

 


Last Modified: 08/27/2021
Modified by: Charles Setterfield
